Guided Walkthrough

Walkthrough 1: Configuring Branch Protection

Let‚Äôs set up comprehensive protection for a production branch.

Step 1: Navigate to Branch Protection 1. Go to your repository on GitHub.com 2. Click Settings ‚Üí Branches 3. Under ‚ÄúBranch protection rules‚Äù, click Add rule

Step 2: Define the Branch Pattern

Branch name pattern: main

This will protect:
‚úì main
‚úó main-backup (doesn't match exactly)
‚úó feature/main (doesn't match)

For multiple branches, use patterns:

  • release/* - All release branches
  • main - Exact match
  • * - All branches (careful!)

Step 3: Configure Protection Options

‚òë Require a pull request before merging
  ‚òë Require approvals: 2
  ‚òë Dismiss stale pull request approvals when new commits are pushed
  ‚òë Require review from Code Owners
  ‚òë Require approval of the most recent reviewable push

‚òë Require status checks to pass before merging
  ‚òë Require branches to be up to date before merging
  Status checks that are required:
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ci/build
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ci/test
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ security/codeql

‚òë Require conversation resolution before merging

‚òë Require signed commits

‚òë Require linear history

‚òê Do not allow bypassing the above settings
  (Enable this for highest security)

‚òë Restrict who can push to matching branches
  Allowed: @release-team

Step 4: Save and Test 1. Click Create or Save changes 2. Try pushing directly to main - should fail 3. Create a PR - protection rules apply

Walkthrough 2: Creating a CODEOWNERS File

Step 1: Create the File

Create .github/CODEOWNERS:

# Default owners for everything
*                           @myorg/engineering-leads

# Frontend code
/src/components/            @myorg/frontend-team
/src/styles/                @myorg/frontend-team @myorg/design-team
*.css                       @myorg/frontend-team
*.tsx                       @myorg/frontend-team

# Backend code
/src/api/                   @myorg/backend-team
/src/services/              @myorg/backend-team
*.py                        @myorg/backend-team

# Infrastructure
/terraform/                 @myorg/platform-team
/kubernetes/                @myorg/platform-team
/.github/workflows/         @myorg/platform-team
Dockerfile                  @myorg/platform-team

# Security-sensitive files (multiple required reviewers)
/src/auth/                  @security-lead @myorg/security-team
/src/crypto/                @security-lead @myorg/security-team
*.pem                       @security-lead
*.key                       @security-lead

# Documentation
/docs/                      @myorg/docs-team
*.md                        @myorg/docs-team
README.md                   @myorg/engineering-leads

# Configuration files
package.json                @myorg/frontend-team
requirements.txt            @myorg/backend-team
.env.example                @myorg/platform-team @myorg/security-team

Step 2: Enable CODEOWNERS Requirement

In branch protection rules:

‚òë Require review from Code Owners

Step 3: Verify CODEOWNERS is Working

  1. Create a PR that modifies /src/api/endpoint.py
  2. GitHub should automatically request review from @myorg/backend-team
  3. The PR cannot be merged until a CODEOWNER approves

Walkthrough 3: Setting Up Repository Rulesets

Step 1: Navigate to Rulesets 1. Repository Settings ‚Üí Rules ‚Üí Rulesets 2. Click New ruleset ‚Üí New branch ruleset

Step 2: Configure Ruleset Basics

Ruleset Name: Production Branch Protection
Enforcement status: Active
Bypass list:
  ‚òë Repository admin
  ‚òë Specific actors:
      - github-actions[bot]
      - release-automation

Step 3: Define Target Branches

Target branches:
  ‚òë Add target ‚Üí Include by pattern
      Pattern: main
  ‚òë Add target ‚Üí Include by pattern
      Pattern: release/*

Step 4: Configure Rules

‚òë Restrict creations
‚òë Restrict deletions
‚òë Restrict updates
‚òë Block force pushes

‚òë Require pull request before merging
    Required approvals: 2
    Dismiss stale reviews: ‚òë
    Require review from CODEOWNERS: ‚òë
    Require last push approval: ‚òë

‚òë Require status checks to pass
    Required checks:
      - build
      - test
      - security-scan
    ‚òë Require branches to be up to date

‚òë Require signed commits
‚òë Require linear history

Step 5: Create Organization Ruleset (Enterprise)

For organization-wide rules:

  1. Go to Organization Settings ‚Üí Rules ‚Üí Rulesets
  2. Create ruleset with target repositories: Target repositories: ‚òë All repositories OR ‚òë Include by pattern: *-production

Walkthrough 4: Setting Up Commit Signing

Option A: SSH Key Signing (Recommended)

Step 1: Configure Git to Use SSH Signing

# Set SSH signing format
git config --global gpg.format ssh

# Specify your SSH signing key
git config --global user.signingkey ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

# Enable automatic signing
git config --global commit.gpgsign true
git config --global tag.gpgsign true

Step 2: Add Signing Key to GitHub 1. Go to Settings ‚Üí SSH and GPG keys 2. Click New SSH key 3. Select Signing Key as Key type 4. Paste your public key

Step 3: Create Allowed Signers File (for local verification)

# Create allowed_signers file
echo "your.email@company.com $(cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub)" > ~/.ssh/allowed_signers

# Configure git to use it
git config --global gpg.ssh.allowedSignersFile ~/.ssh/allowed_signers

Option B: GPG Signing

Step 1: Generate GPG Key

# Generate new GPG key
gpg --full-generate-key

# List keys to get ID
gpg --list-secret-keys --keyid-format=long

# Output shows:
# sec   ed25519/ABC123DEF456 2024-01-01
#       ABC123DEF456 is your key ID

Step 2: Configure Git

git config --global user.signingkey ABC123DEF456
git config --global commit.gpgsign true

Step 3: Export and Add to GitHub

# Export public key
gpg --armor --export ABC123DEF456

# Add to GitHub Settings ‚Üí SSH and GPG keys ‚Üí New GPG key

Walkthrough 5: Creating a GitHub Release

Step 1: Prepare Release Configuration

Create .github/release.yml:

changelog:
  exclude:
    labels:
      - skip-changelog
      - dependencies
    authors:
      - dependabot[bot]
      - github-actions[bot]
  categories:
    - title: üéâ New Features
      labels:
        - enhancement
        - feature
    - title: üêõ Bug Fixes
      labels:
        - bug
        - bugfix
    - title: ‚ö° Performance
      labels:
        - performance
    - title: üîí Security
      labels:
        - security
    - title: üìö Documentation
      labels:
        - documentation
        - docs
    - title: üß∞ Maintenance
      labels:
        - chore
        - maintenance
        - refactor
    - title: Other Changes
      labels:
        - "*"

Step 2: Create Release via UI

  1. Go to repository ‚Üí Releases ‚Üí Draft a new release
  2. Click Choose a tag ‚Üí Enter v1.2.0 ‚Üí Create new tag
  3. Set Target to main (or specific commit)
  4. Enter Release title: v1.2.0 - Feature Release
  5. Click Generate release notes to auto-populate
  6. Edit release notes as needed
  7. Attach binary assets (drag and drop)
  8. Choose release type:
    • ‚òë Set as the latest release
    • ‚òê Set as a pre-release
  9. Click Publish release

Step 3: Create Release via CLI

# Using GitHub CLI
gh release create v1.2.0 \
  --title "v1.2.0 - Feature Release" \
  --notes-file CHANGELOG.md \
  --target main \
  ./dist/app-linux.tar.gz \
  ./dist/app-macos.tar.gz \
  ./dist/app-windows.zip

# Create pre-release
gh release create v1.3.0-beta.1 \
  --title "v1.3.0 Beta 1" \
  --prerelease \
  --generate-notes
